title: React2Shell: Critical RCE in React Server Components (CVSS 10.0, CISA KEV)
affected_products: Any framework using React Server Components

timeline.event: Lachlan Davidson discovers vulnerability and discloses to React Team
React Team releases security advisory and patches (19.0.1, 19.1.2, 19.2.1)
First exploitation attempts detected in the wild
CISA adds CVE-2025-55182 to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
China state-nexus groups (Earth Lamia, Jackpot Panda) begin active exploitation
CISA deadline for federal agencies to patch

simple_summary.what_happened: A critical remote code execution vulnerability (CVSS 10.0) was discovered in React Server Components, dubbed React2Shell. The flaw allows attackers to execute arbitrary code on servers through a single malicious HTTP request without any authentication. Default configurations created with create-next-app are vulnerable with no code changes required.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Any organization running React 19.x or Next.js 15.x/16.x with App Router is vulnerable. This includes millions of web applications running on cloud platforms. The vulnerability particularly impacts internet-facing Next.js frontends and React Server Component workloads running in Kubernetes clusters and managed PaaS platforms.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Attacker identifies a vulnerable React Server Components application. Step 2: Crafts a malicious HTTP request exploiting unsafe deserialization in the Flight protocol. Step 3: Injects arbitrary objects that get deserialized in privileged server contexts. Step 4: Executes arbitrary code on the server. Step 5: Harvests cloud credentials (AWS, Azure, GCP tokens, Kubernetes service accounts). Step 6: Deploys cryptominers, backdoors, or moves laterally to other cloud resources.
what_you_should_do: Immediately upgrade React to patched versions: 19.0.1, 19.1.2, or 19.2.1
Upgrade Next.js to latest patched version
Enable AWS WAF with AWSManagedRulesKnownBadInputsRuleSet (v1.24+) for automatic protection
Use Microsoft Defender for Cloud agentless scanning to detect vulnerable containers
Review logs for suspicious deserialization patterns
Rotate cloud credentials if running vulnerable versions
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: React powers millions of web applications worldwide. State-sponsored threat groups from China are actively exploiting this vulnerability within hours of disclosure. The attack requires no authentication and works against default configurations. CISA has added it to the mandatory patch list. Compromised servers can lead to cloud account takeover, data theft, and cryptomining.

tactics.description: Arbitrary code execution through unsafe deserialization
Harvesting cloud credentials from IMDS endpoints (AWS, Azure, GCP)
Using stolen cloud tokens to access other resources
Deploying cryptocurrency miners on compromised infrastructure

detection_guidance.summary: Monitor for suspicious HTTP requests with unusual serialization patterns targeting React Server Components endpoints. Look for attempts to access cloud metadata services after exploitation.

log_sources.description: Next.js/React server logs for unusual request patterns
Cloudflare, AWS WAF, Azure WAF logs for blocked exploit attempts
Kubernetes/Docker logs for unexpected process spawning
CloudTrail, Azure Activity Logs for unusual API calls post-exploitation

what_to_look_for.description: HTTP requests with suspicious serialized objects in the body
what_to_look_for.log_field: Request body containing unexpected object prototypes

what_to_look_for.description: Requests to 169.254.169.254 from web application processes
what_to_look_for.log_field: Network connections to cloud metadata endpoints

what_to_look_for.description: Node.js spawning shell processes (sh, bash, curl, wget)
what_to_look_for.log_field: Process creation events from node processes

what_to_look_for.description: High CPU usage, connections to mining pools
what_to_look_for.log_field: Network connections to known mining pool domains

immediate_actions.description: Identify all applications using vulnerable React 19.x or Next.js 15.x/16.x
Upgrade to React 19.0.1, 19.1.2, or 19.2.1 and latest Next.js
Enable AWS WAF with managed rule set or equivalent on other platforms
Use container scanning tools to identify vulnerable deployments
Check for suspicious API calls that may indicate post-exploitation activity
If running vulnerable versions, rotate all cloud credentials and API keys
